title: Add command line support for ext_migrate tool
body:
Make /scripts into package and change setup.py to allow for command line execution of the import migration tool (#1342).

While updating the docs for #1366 I realized I needed to make the import migration tool easily executed through the command line. I will wait on submitting changes to #1366 until we can decide on how to implement use of the tool.

comments_inline.body: I don't think redbaron should be in `install_requires`. You need the migration tool exactly once, and never on a production system. So making it hard dependency would probably be overkill.
Good point @ThiefMaster. I was not sure whether it would be more user friendly to include it, but your comment makes sense.

Also, both `ext_migrate` as a CLI tool and `scripts` as a top-level package are way too generic in my opinion. `flask_ext_migrate` would be better, but I'm not sure if it makes lots of sense to install it by default... Maybe it'd be better to keep it in `scripts` and have people run it using `python -m flask.scripts.flaskext_migrate` (or something like that)
I thought of simply instructing users to install redbaron manually and executing the script would be enough.

To summarize changes:
1. RedBaron has been removed as a Flask install dependency and moved to extras_requires
2. The name of the command has been changed to `flask_ext_migrate` to make it more specific
3. The test module import was changed to reflect that `scripts` is now a top-level package
4. An unused import statement was removed from the test module (Thanks @ThiefMaster).

I feel that having `scripts` as a top-level package simplifies usage of the tool and also allows for further command line tool development downstream. Is this bad practice though? I can certainly change it.

I don't think having `scripts` as a top-level package is acceptable, the name is way too generic:

```
import scripts
```

Maybe make the tool a part of the `flask` command?
Sure, reading about this now. I will format `flaskext_migrate.py` to follow the convention used here: http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/dev/cli/#custom-scripts
I'm not sure though... maybe we really should leave it as-is.

I agree that `scripts` is very generic, but think it should remain as is. Mainly because it doesn't appear that the `flask` command is meant for this purpose. For now I will leave this PR as is until there can be a consensus.

a global scripts package is absolutely unacceptable since it would go straight into site-packages

i'm wondering if the complete migration tool should be a separate python package install able only via a extra requirement

Do you mean we should have it as a recommended package or still include it in the flask code, maybe something like this?

```
|-- flask
    |-- scripts
        |-- test_import_migration.py
        |-- flask_ext_migrate
            |-- setup.py
            |-- flask_ext_migrate
                |-- __init__.py
                |-- flaskext_migrate.py
```

And then just suggest in the docs that users `pip install flask_ext_migrate`? I'm open to whatever, just not sure what you are suggesting.

the command should be `pip install flask[ext_migrate]` in any case

if its a separate package maintaining it inside of flask would be problematic
but we certainly should not put the name scripts into the global python name-space

in my opinion we should either have the code in `flask.scripts.ext_migrate`
or create a separate python package with flask just referring to it in a extras_require

other opinions/impressions are welcome
Perhaps make the script its own project and repo?

I'm concerned that moving it into it's own repo would make maintaining it difficult, as @RonnyPfannschmidt suggested.

How can we have the code in `flask.scripts.ext_migrate` if we don't have a top-level package in `setup.py`? I think I favor this approach, but I'm not sure how to do it.
a complete own repo is fine actually, just not making a project inside a project
a complete own repo would even ease deprecation, sine removing the extra requirement is a completely non-breaking change, while removing the code would be
Fair enough, where should the repo go? Under pocoo?
Yeah, only @mitsuhiko has access for that though.
Anyone else that can make the repo? I'd like to keep working on this and not have it get stalled, I'm worried he is too busy to do this.
He only needs to make the repo... we (you) can still get commit rights for it.
Can someone ask him? I've never actually been successful at contacting him.
Will look into it.

I've changed my mind again: I think we should instruct people to install redbaron manually and run the script from the repo directly. With proper documentation, I can't see any disadvantages of this approach, given that this is a script that is probably used once and never again.

With this reasoning, I'd like to close this PR.

@keyan Welcome to the team!

We now have https://github.com/pocoo/flask-ext-migrate, see https://github.com/pocoo/metaflask on how to get access there.
Great! Thanks @untitaker!
@keyan Do you need help with getting push access to that repo?
@untitaker Thanks, but I think I have push access already. I've just been busy with other week this past week. I am working on it though and I'll try to push what I have this week.
